lead_paragraph: In its 19th-century beginnings, New York Life Insurance sold 508 policies covering slaves. Their descendants are grappling with it.

byline.contributor: Kitty Bennett and Doris Burke contributed research.

headline.print_headline: Reckoning With a Legacy of Insuring Slaves’ Lives
headline.main: Insurance Policies on Slaves: New York Life’s Complicated Past

snippet: In its 19th-century beginnings, New York Life Insurance sold 508 policies covering slaves. Their descendants are grappling with it....
abstract: New York Life, nation's third-largest insurance company, began insuring lives of Southerners' slaves in 1846, with insurance policies on slaves accounting for third of company's polices by 1847; legacy underscores ties that contemporary institutions, even those in North, have to painful period in nation's history.
